title: Simone Jatobá
text:
Simone Gomes Jatobá (born 10 February 1981), commonly known as Simone, is a Brazilian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Coach%20%28sports%29">coach</a> and former player. She was appointed coach of the <a href="Brazil%20women%27s%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Brazil women's national under-17 football team</a> in August 2019.
Club career.
Simone began her career in <a href="Campeonato%20Brasileiro%20de%20Futebol%20Feminino">Campeonato Brasileiro</a>'s Ponte Preta, <a href="Santos%20FC%20%28women%29">Santos FC</a> and <a href="Saad%20EC">Saad EC</a>. In 2004, she moved to <a href="Rayo%20Vallecano%20%28women%29">Rayo Vallecano</a> in the <a href="Spain">Spanish</a> <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20%28women%29">Superliga</a>, and next year she signed for <a href="Olympique%20Lyonnais%20%28Ladies%29">Olympique Lyonnais</a>, where she played for the next five years. She was a solid contributor to the squads that won the league in 2007 and 2008, as well as the squad that won the <a href="Coupe%20de%20France">Challenge de France</a> in 2008. In 2010, she returned to Brazil, playing for <a href="Novo%20Mundo%20FC">Novo Mundo FC</a>, but two years later she signed for <a href="Energiya%20Voronezh">Energiya Voronezh</a> in the <a href="Russian%20women%27s%20football%20championship">Russian Championship</a>.
In June 2019 38-year-old Simone left <a href="FC%20Metz%20%28women%29">FC Metz</a> after five seasons and retired from playing football.
International career.
In June 2000 Simone made her international debut in <a href="Brazil%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a>'s 8–0 <a href="2000%20CONCACAF%20Women%27s%20Gold%20Cup">CONCACAF Women's Gold Cup</a> win over <a href="Costa%20Rica%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Costa Rica</a> at <a href="Hersheypark%20Stadium">Hersheypark Stadium</a>, <a href="Hershey%2C%20Pennsylvania">Hershey, Pennsylvania</a>. As a 19-year-old she played at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">2000 Sydney Olympics</a>, where Brazil finished fourth after losing 2–0 to <a href="Germany%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a> in the bronze medal match at <a href="Sydney%20Football%20Stadium">Sydney Football Stadium</a>.
Simone has been a part of two <a href="FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> squads. She was a part of the squad from <a href="2003%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2003</a> that finished as quarter-finalists and the squad that finished in second place in <a href="2007%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">China</a>. She also participated in the <a href="Football%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a>, again helping Brazil finish one spot short in second place.
She usually plays as a right <a href="winger%20%28football%29">winger</a> for the <a href="Brazil%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Brazilian National Team</a>.
Personal life.
Her uncle <a href="Carlos%20Roberto%20Jatob%C3%A1">Carlos Roberto Jatobá</a> was also a professional footballer.
